newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain lowers inflation target - Aznar interview.
newsitem.headline: Spain lowers inflation target - Aznar interview.

text.p: Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar said in an interview published on Sunday that the Spanish government was lowering its 1997 inflation target to 2.2 percent from an earlier estimate of 2.6 percent.

Aznar told the Spanish news agency Europa Press the move resulted from a better-than-expected economic performance and he hoped it would improve Spain's prospects for being one of the founding members of European monetary union in 1999.

"The inflation target should now be set at 2.2 (percent)," Aznar was quoted as saying. Data released last Wednesday showed inflation fell to 1.7 percent in April, the lowest in nearly three decades, from 2.2 percent in March.
